evidence.dc:description: Distinct craniofacial dysmorphisms are among the phenotypic characteristics of the intellectual disability-craniofacial dysmorphism-cryptorchidism syndrome in humans. Using mutant human PACS1 mRNA in a zebrafish model, the authors observe craniofacial defects that recapitulate the human disease phenotype. This craniofacial phenotype, induced upon over-expression of mutant mRNA, was rescued with the injection of an equal ratio of wild-type and mutant mRNA, suggesting a dominant negative mechanism of disease. They further reported that the significant reduction in craniofacial structures upon expression of mutant PACS1 mRNA was at least in part due to the loss of cranial-neural-crest cell-derived progenitors that showed a significant reduction in migration in the anterior-most region of the embryo. Examining specificity, the authors find that the observed migration phenotype is not observed in enteric-neural-crest cells but is instead specific to the cranial-neural-crest cells. Altogether, their findings suggest that PACS1 can promote the specification and migration of cranial-neural-crest cells that give rise to the majority of skeletal and connective tissues in the face.

dc:source.dc:abstract: We studied two unrelated boys with intellectual disability (ID) and a striking facial resemblance suggestive of a hitherto unappreciated syndrome. Exome sequencing in both families identified identical de novo mutations in PACS1, suggestive of causality. To support these genetic findings and to understand the pathomechanism of the mutation, we studied the protein in vitro and in vivo. Altered PACS1 forms cytoplasmic aggregates in vitro with concomitant increased protein stability and shows impaired binding to an isoform-specific variant of TRPV4, but not the full-length protein. Furthermore, consistent with the human pathology, expression of mutant PACS1 mRNA in zebrafish embryos induces craniofacial defects most likely in a dominant-negative fashion. This phenotype is driven by aberrant specification and migration of SOX10-positive cranial, but not enteric, neural-crest cells. Our findings suggest that PACS1 is necessary for the formation of craniofacial structures and that perturbation of its functions results in a specific syndromic ID phenotype.
dc:source.dc:creator: Schuurs-Hoeijmakers JH
dc:source.dc:title: Recurrent de novo mutations in PACS1 cause defective cranial-neural-crest migration and define a recognizable intellectual-disability syndrome.

evidence.rdfs:label: In vivo functional characterization of p.Arg203Trp in PACS1

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Developmental delay; gross motor delay; nonverbal; intellectual disability; dysmorphic facial features including flat occiput, mild downslanting palpebral fissures, fully arched eyebrows, saddle nose with wide bulbous tip and slightly upturned nares, thin upper lip with wide mouth and downturned corners, peg-shaped teeth with normal palate, and short neck without webbing; bilateral iris and retinal coloboma; abnormal fingers; pes planus; constipation; gastroesophageal reflux; repetitive behaviors; very high pain threshold; scoliosis; lordosis; pectus excavatum; distal limb abnormalities include hypermobility of finger joints, increased fingertip pads, relative brachydactyly of the fingers, flat feet, short toes and a large space between the first and second toes.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Karyotype and fluorescence in situ hybridization for subtelomeric deletions were both normal. Single nucleotide polymorphism chromosome microarray was also normal. Full sequencing of CHD7 was normal.  Multiple ligation-dependent probe amplification analysis and full sequencing of MECP2 were normal.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Heterozygous mutation in the PACS1 (phosphofurin acidic cluster sorting proteins 1) gene is a known cause of developmental delay, multiple congenital anomalies, dysmorphism, and ocular abnormalities. We present the case of an affected 10-year-old girl, conceived by assisted reproductive technology, who has ocular coloboma and findings characteristic of PACS1 mutation.
dc:source.dc:creator: Pefkianaki M
dc:source.dc:title: Ocular manifestations of PACS1 mutation.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient

evidence.dc:description: The causative PACS1 mutation normally de novo in previously reported patients is of unknown inheritance in this proband

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Developmental delay/intellectual disability; abnormal growth (> 90th percentile in weight, height and open fontanelle); abnormal speech; seizures; dilatation of main pulmonary artery (cardiac defect); dysmorphic features include epicanthal folds, short and broad neck, broad nasal bridge, and camptodactyly of fifth fingers.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Developmental delay/ intellectual disability; language development more severely affected; characteristic facial dysmorphisms; seizures; dystonia, recurrent sinus infections, frenulum linguae; clinodactyly of 5th finger; persistent left superior vena cava; optic nerve, bilateral; mild colpocephaly; paucity of cerebral white matter; diminutive body of the corpus callosum; abnormal cerebral imaging

dc:source.dc:abstract: We report on 19 individuals with a recurrent de novo c.607C>T mutation in PACS1. This specific mutation gives rise to a recognizable intellectual disability syndrome. There is a distinctive facial appearance (19/19), characterized by full and arched eyebrows, hypertelorism with downslanting palpebral fissures, long eye lashes, ptosis, low set and simple ears, bulbous nasal tip, wide mouth with downturned corners and a thin upper lip with an unusual "wavy" profile, flat philtrum, and diastema of the teeth. Intellectual disability, ranging from mild to moderate, was present in all. Hypotonia is common in infancy (8/19). Seizures are frequent (12/19) and respond well to anticonvulsive medication. Structural malformations are common, including heart (10/19), brain (12/16), eye (10/19), kidney (3/19), and cryptorchidism (6/12 males). Feeding dysfunction is presenting in infancy with failure to thrive (5/19), gastroesophageal reflux (6/19), and gastrostomy tube placement (4/19). There is persistence of oral motor dysfunction. We provide suggestions for clinical work-up and management and hope that the present study will facilitate clinical recognition of further cases.
dc:source.dc:creator: Schuurs-Hoeijmakers JH
dc:source.dc:title: Clinical delineation of the PACS1-related syndrome--Report on 19 patients.

dc:source.dc:title: A novel missense mutation affecting the same amino acid as the recurrent PACS1 mutation in Schuurs-Hoeijmakers syndrome.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient

evidence.detectionMethod: Trio-based whole exome sequencing and Sanger sequencing were used to identify and confirm the variant.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Developmental delay (speech more severely affected); overgrowth phenotype from birth involving tall stature, macrocephaly, and large, broad hands and feet; clinodactyly and camptodactyly of the fifth finger; high plantar arches without evidence of a neuropathy; dysmorphic facial features include hypertelorism, downslanting palpebral fissures, eversion of the lateral third of lower eyelids, a bulbous nasal tip, long philtrum, thin upper vermilion, a wide mouth with downturned corners and low-set ears; persistent ductus arteriosus; patent foramen ovale and bicuspid aortic valve without haemodynamic consequences. Specifically noted unexpected phenotypes include long foot, long palm, macrocephaly, overgrowth, tall stature, mild expressive language delay, camptodactyly of finger, talipes equinovarus, recurrent pneumonia, and abnormality of complement system.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Developmental delay; intellectual disability; Dysmorphic facial features include a low anterior hairline, arched eyebrows, low‐set ears, hypertelorism with downslanting palpebral fissures, anteverted nose, a bulbous nasal tip, a tented and thin upper lip, and a wide mouth with downturned corners; seizures; tapered fingers; constipation; muscular hypotonia; small muscular ventricular septal defect; right coloboma of the optic nerve head and iris; non-epileptic involuntary movements (treated with trihexyphenidyl hydrochloride); behavioral issue; abnormal brain MRI; pes planus; abnormal fingers

dc:source.dc:abstract: Schuurs-Hoeijmakers syndrome is a rare disease characterized by intellectual disability and dysmorphic facial features among various physical abnormalities due to PACS1 mutation. To date, 28 patients with a recurrent de novo PACS1 mutation (c.607C > T) have been reported, primarily in Western populations. Here, we describe two Japanese patients with Schuurs-Hoeijmakers syndrome with a recurrent PACS1 mutation. In addition to the typical clinical symptoms, each patient presented novel clinical phenotypes. One patient presented with involuntary movements and was treated with trihexyphenidyl hydrochloride. We hypothesized that the PACS1 mutation leads to an inherent dopaminergic insufficiency that underlies the developing symptoms along with the neurodevelopmental processes. The second patient was diagnosed with lipomyelomeningocele during an examination for severe constipation at the age of 2 years and 8 months. The diagnosis of lipomyelomeningocele in this patient was delayed due to the lack of cutaneous lesions. As the majority of patients with PACS1 mutation present constipation, underdiagnosis of lipomyelomeningocele is a possibility. As the phenotypic expansion of the patients with Schuurs-Hoeijmakers syndrome was not fully recognized, additional studies are needed to clarify the clinical spectrum.
dc:source.dc:creator: Hoshino Y
dc:source.dc:title: Schuurs-Hoeijmakers syndrome in two patients from Japan.

evidence.detectionMethod: Trio whole exome sequencing was performed on a HiSeq 2500 sequencer. Sanger sequencing confirmed de novo status of variant.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Intellectual disability; moderate global developmental delay; facial features include a prominent forehead with high frontal hair line, hypertelorism, prominent epicanthal folds, downslanting palpebral fissures, long eyelashes, highly arched eyebrows, a bulbous tip of the nose, a smooth philtrum, a wide mouth with downturned corners, thin upper lips with the shape of a cupid´s bow, large, posteriorly rotated low-set ears, and curly and temporarily sparse scalp hair; congenital heart defect (patent ductus arteriosus, atrial septal defect, and small ventricular septal defect); chronic constipation; neonatal hypotonia, low levels of immunoglobulins, and poor weight gain; weak sucking reflex. Other physical characteristics include a short neck, widely spaced nipples, a single transverse palmar crease, slightly tapering fingers, clinodactyly of the 5th fingers and pes adductus.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Conventional chromosomal analysis revealed a normal karyotype and microarray analysis two small deletions (110 kb each) on 2q13 and 16p13.3, which were inherited from the healthy father and were therefore considered not to be disease causing. Since the clinical presentation was reminiscent of a disorder from the rasopathy spectrum, sequence analysis of PTPN11, KRAS, SOS1 and RAF1 was performed, but did not reveal disease causing variants.

evidence.detectionMethod: Exome sequencing was performed on DNA from proband-parent trio using the ABI SOLiD 4 platform. Sanger sequencing confirmed de novo status of variant.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Intellectual disability; left-sided cryptorchidism; developmental delay (language production was more delayed than verbal understanding and dyspraxia was noted); stereotypic movements; facial features include a low anterior hairline, hypertelorism with downslanting palpebral fissures, mild synophrys with highly arched eyebrows, long eyelashes, a bulbous nose, a flat philtrum, large, low-set ears, wide mouth with downturned corners, a thin upper lip, and diastema of the teeth. Other physical characteristics include widely spaced nipples, slender fingers (but broad and short thumbs), clubbed nails, a single transverse palmar crease on the left hand, and pes planus.
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
Conventional karyotyping, as well as SNP array testing (Affymetrix, 250K), showed a normal male karyotype.
Because of some facial similarities to Cornelia de Lange syndrome (MIM 122470), NIPBL (MIM 608667), SMC1A (MIM 300040), and SMC3 (MIM 606062) were sequenced for mutations, but none were found.

Other physical characteristics include a short neck, widely spaced nipples, a mild pectus excavatum, mild scoliosis, clinodactyly, shortness of the fifth fingers, mild cutaneous webbing of the fingers, multiple pigmented nevi, small umbilical hernia, and hypoplastic scrotum.

The variant was confirmed by Sanger sequencing in the patient but absent in the unaffected parents.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Severe developmental delay/intellectual disability; language delay (no speech); autism spectrum disorder; hyperactivity; microcephaly; dysmorphic features include low-set ears, long eyelashes, hypertelorism, bulbous nasal tip, unilateral cleft lip (repaired), thin upper lip, wide mouth, and bilateral iris coloboma (also extending to the choroid and retina).

dc:source.dc:abstract: Schuurs-Hoeijmakers syndrome (SHMS), or Autosomal Dominant Mental Retardation Syndrome type 17 (MRD17) is a rare form of intellectual disability with distinct facial features. A recurrent de novo heterozygous c.607C>T, p.Arg203Trp mutation in the PACS1 gene accounts for all reported cases except for one patient with a de novo heterozygous c.608G>A, p.Arg203Trp mutation. Ethnic background is known to affect the clinical manifestation of dysmorphic syndromes. Here we describe the first Indian patient with Schuurs-Hoeijmakers syndrome (SHMS) with a de novo heterozygous NM_018026.3 (PACS1):c.607C>T (p.Arg203Trp) variant. He is the only child with SHMS with a cleft lip. Thus our report expands the phenotypic spectrum of SHMS and establishes its occurrence across populations.
dc:source.dc:creator: Dutta AK
dc:source.dc:title: Schuurs-Hoeijmakers syndrome in a patient from India.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient

evidence.dc:description: Given the surplus of probands to be scored aside from this publication and the use of next generation sequencing gene panel rather than whole exome sequencing for variant detection, this patient does not need to be scored.

dc:description:
PACS1 was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant Schuurs-Hoeijmakers syndrome in 2012 (Schuurs-Hoeijmakers et al., 23159249). At least 2 unique missense variants (NM_018026.4(PACS1):c.607C>T (p.Arg203Trp) & NM_018026.3(PACS1): c.608G>A (p.Arg203Gln)) have been reported in humans. All but one reported cases are due to the Arg203Trp mutation. Miyake et al. 2018 (PMID: 28975623) reported the first and only case of Arg203Gln and described the same distinctive facial dysmorphisms characteristic of the Schuurs-Hoeijmakers syndrome. These features typically include full, arched eyebrows, hypertelorism, down-slanting palpebral fissures, long eyelashes, ptosis, low-set, large ears, bulbous tip of nose, flat philtrum, wide mouth with downturned corners and thin upper lip with a wavy profile, and diastema of the teeth. Other common phenotypes include intellectual disability, delayed speech development, cryptorchidism in males, seizures, hypotonia, and congenital anomalies affecting the heart, brain, or eye. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level and experimental data.
Summary of Case Level Data: 12 points. 
Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 33 probands in nine publications (PMIDs: 23159249, 25522177, 26842493, 28111752, 30113927, 28975623, 29550517, 30690871, 30588754). Among these, six probands from four publications (PMIDs: 23159249, 25522177, 28975623, 30588754) were selected to be scored based on confirmed de novo status, representation of the variant spectrum, diversity in ethnic groups, and variant detection via trio-based exome sequencing. 
Summary of Experimental Data: 2 points.
This gene-disease association is supported by in vivo functional assays in a non-human model organism. To understand the mechanistic basis of the human dysmorphic phenotype, Schuurs-Hoeijmakers et al 2012 (PMID: 23159249) studied the behavior of the p.Arg203Trp substitution in craniofacial cartilaginous structures in zebrafish embryos and found that the expression of mutant PACS1 mRNA in zebrafish embryos induces craniofacial defects most likely in a dominant-negative fashion and that this phenotype is driven by aberrant specification and migration of SOX10-positive cranial, but not enteric, neural-crest cells. 
In summary, PACS1 is definitively associated with autosomal dominant, Schuurs-Hoeijmakers syndrome also known as the intellectual disability-craniofacial dysmorphism-cryptorchidism syndrome. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Intellectual Disability and Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel on June 16, 2020 (SOP Version 7).
